Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Enabling control of Bacillus subtilis growth using non-standard amino acids

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project seeks to create tools that control the abundance of specific essential proteins in Bacillus subtilis by making them depend on unnatural amino acids. B. subtilis is a soil-dwelling microbe used to stimulate plant growth and to improve intestinal health in animals and humans. B. subtilis is also a model system for studying cell shape and division. The cellular machinery that orchestrates cell elongation and division include numerous components, several of which are poorly understood, and for which there are few tools to carefully control their abundance. This project aims to modify B. subtilis such that the abundance of target proteins is controlled by the concentration of non-standard amino acid supplied in the culture media. An analogy for this project is the construction of a dimmer switch for a light in a room. The new switch allows one to dim the brightness of a light that must stay on, where previously the only option was to increase brightness relative to the default setting. If one can dim the light in a room, then it is possible that one will see new features in the room and understand how little light is needed to keep the room functional. In addition to this research, undergraduate students who participate in the nascent International Genetically Engineered Machines (iGEM) team at the University of Delaware will receive lab space and mentoring to conduct projects related to non-standard amino acids. This project is jointly funded by the Systems and Synthetic Biology program and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

The imposition of translational control allows precise control of expression, including weaker and stronger expressions than natural promoters in B. subtilis. This will complement existing approaches that are geared towards transcriptional control for overexpression. This project will explore the use of engineered aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase and tRNA pairs in both E. coli and B. subtilis to compare amber codon suppression across enzyme families and across organism. Upon achievement of non-standard amino acid incorporation in B. subtilis, the project will investigate the ability to titrate extracellular amino acid concentration and achieve dose-dependent translation of a model fluorescent protein. This project then aims to use this new control strategy to interrogate cell wall synthesis and to explore the extension of synthetic auxotrophy. Cell morphology and length will be studied as components of the cell wall synthesis machinery are titrated, shedding light on what protein concentrations are required to achieve normal cell shapes. Synthetic auxotrophy is a promising intrinsic biological containment technique where an organism is engineered to depend on a synthetic nutrient for its growth. Because this biocontainment technique has only been demonstrated thus far in E. coli, this project will examine whether similar auxotrophic markers or the modifications to cell wall synthesis machinery can achieve robust reliance of the organism on non-standard amino acids for its growth.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Development of nsAA incorporation in Bacillus subtilis - Our main objective was to expand the genetic code of B. subtilis. This means we take a sequence on DNA that says “stop translating proteins,” and instead develop a series of genetic modifications so that rather than stopping making protein when the ribosome sees these stop codons, it incorporates a “non-standard amino acid” (or nsAA) into these positions. These nsAAs are added to the outside of cells and are different than normal amino acids: they are ones designed through chemistry that can then provide a series of different chemical features, allowing us to do new things with proteins inside cells.  These engineering efforts have led to our incorporation of 20 different nsAAs into B. subtilis proteins, an ability conferred by utilizing 3 different families of orthogonal aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase and their cognate tRNAs. Among these 20, this included nsAAs that function as fluorescent probe handles for click chemistry, photo-crosslinkers, and metal chelation.

Demonstration of nsAA titration of protein expression – One specific nsAA, pAzF, was able to go into cells and incorporate into proteins during exponential growth. We tested if pAzF would allow very precise control of protein expression at the translational level, as its incorporation is required for full-length protein synthesis. These efforts were a success, and we could indeed titrate the expression of fluorescent proteins by exogenous addition of nsAAs. Strikingly, nsAA-induced protein translation yielded a far more linear response to nsAAs than the standard inducible promoters used in the bacterial field.  As a demonstration that nsAA titration can control the expression of proteins with extremely sensitive concentration-dependent effects, we titrated the expression of MciZ, a protein that binds to FtsZ polymers that form the division Z-ring. While high expression with standard promoters causes Z rings to depolymerize, our nsAA-dependent titration was able to carefully and stability titrate MciZ expression, allowing us to observe that FtsZ filament length was reduced, and treadmilling speed increased, effects that have only been previously observed in vitro. 

Non-specific incorporation of nsAAs into proteins in B. subtilis - One use of nsAA incorporation is fluorescent tagging proteins in cells. We attempted to use Coumarin-nsAA (CouAA) incorporation to localize proteins involved in cell division. However, in contrast to what is observed in E. coli, we observed that the fluorescent nsAA was incorporated non-specifically into many proteins, indicating this technology cannot be used in B. subtilis to specifically label proteins in cells.

Demonstration of nsAA-dependent crosslinking in B. subtilis - One application of nsAAs is the incorporation of UV-photocrosslinking, which allows the ability to test if different proteins are associated in vivo. To test if UV-photocrosslinkable nsAA’s work in B. subtilis, we tested if we could crosslink YukE, a homolog of the mycobacterial virulence factor EsxA that forms homodiamers using pAzF, a nsAA that contains photocrosslinking capabilities of pAzF to demonstrate short-range specific crosslinking between YukE monomers in B. subtilis cells. We were able to crosslink YukE monomers with extremely high efficiency, nearly 100%, with only 15 minutes of UV exposure. Thus, pAzF can be used in B. subtilis to probe oligomerization of and interactions between proteins with UV crosslinking. 

Using nsAA titration (and other promoters) to control the levels of proteins involved in cell elongation and division. We next examined if we could control the levels of proteins involved in the division and elongation of rod-shaped cells. As expected, we were able to control the expression of multiple proteins within the 1) Rod complex and 2) Division machinery, attaining phenotypes similar to what has been previously observed using standard promotors. However, we noted it was extremely difficult to clone nsAA control of expression into many of these genes, a fact that is likely due to the fact that the nsAA system is far less leaky than other promoters, an extremely tight control that makes it hard to clone nsAA control into essential genes. This became most evident in one of our later efforts, putting the gene accDA under pAzF control so we could modulate membrane tension by titrating the rate of phospholipid synthesis. Here, repeated attempts demonstrated this construct would not be incorporated into the genome or be mutated, again demonstrating the tight control conferred by the nsAA system is too tight for some essential genes. Thus, for accDA, we switched to standard promoters, with which we were able to 1) both modulate and measure membrane tension inside the cells, 2) use this control of membrane tension to demonstrate that the condensation of FtsZ filaments into a sharp ring works to overcome the membrane tension to bend the membrane inward to initiate cell division.
